questions.text: A 34-year-old male patient presented to the clinic with a history of diarrhea and poor appetite. He has been having 4-5 episodes of non-bloody, loose stools per day for the last 3 months. A duodenal biopsy is taken and the histopathology is as shown below. Which of the following noninvasive serological studies is the most sensitive to confirm the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette, along with the biopsy image showing villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and lamina propria infiltrates, indicate a case of celiac disease. The most sensitive noninvasive serological test that can be used for diagnosis is the measurement of IgA antibodies against tissue transglutaminase.

Celiac disease is an autoimmune gluten-induced enteropathy. It is associated with HLA DQ2 and DQ8. The pathogenesis of celiac disease involves an inflammatory response to gluten and gliadin (gluten-derived peptide). In the small intestine, gliadin is deamidated by the tissue transglutaminase (tTG), an intestinal enzyme. The deamidated gliadin is more immunogenic and is presented to helper T cells, which mediate mucosal inflammation and cause tissue damage. 

Clinically, patients with celiac disease present with malabsorption syndrome with diarrhoea, abdominal pain, bloating, chronic refractory anaemia, and marked unintentional weight loss. Some patients may also present with dermatitis herpetiformis characterised by blistering lesions caused by the deposition of IgA at the tips of the dermal papillae.

Antiendomysial and anti-tTG antibodies are found in serological studies.

Microscopic findings on biopsy of the proximal small intestine will show villi atrophy, villi flattening, crypt hyperplasia, and increased intraepithelial CD8+ T lymphocytes.

Management of patients with celiac disease involves starting patients on a gluten-free diet.

Related Pearl: Investigations in Malabsorption Syndrome

The following are the general tests for malabsorption:

questions.text: A patient presented with swelling in the buccal cavity. A biopsy of the tissue was done and the histological image is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The histological image shows both epithelial (left) and mesenchymal cell components (right), which is suggestive of pleomorphic adenoma.

Pleomorphic adenomas are the most common salivary gland neoplasms. The parotid gland is the most common site. The submandibular and minor salivary glands are the less common sites. They present as painless, slow-growing, mobile, discrete masses within the parotid or submandibular areas or in the buccal cavity.

Gross features- The tumors are rounded and well-demarcated. They are usually encapsulated, except in some areas such as the palate. The cut surface is gray-white with myxoid and blue translucent areas of the chondroid (cartilage-like) stroma.

Microscopic features consist of:

  • The epithelial elements- They resemble ductal cells or myoepithelial cells. They are arranged as ducts, acini, irregular tubules, strands, or sheets of cells.
  • Mesenchymal elements consisting of loose myxoid and hyaline tissue containing islands of cartilage and, rarely, foci of bone.

Other options: 

Option A - Oncocytomas arise from the kidneys. They are epithelial neoplasms that are composed of large eosinophilic cells with small, round, benign-appearing nuclei with large nucleoli. 

 

Option B - Ductal papillomas arise from the ductal epithelium of the breast. They have multiple branching fibrovascular cores with epithelial hyperplasia and apocrine metaplasia. The following image shows the histological appearance of ductal papilloma. 

 

Option D - Warthin tumors are benign neoplasms of the parotid gland. They appear as round to oval encapsulated masses. Histologically, they have a dense lymphoid stroma with germinal centers, the spaces are narrowed by polypoid projections of lymphoepithelial elements. The upper later has palisading columnar cells and the lower layer has cuboidal to polygonal cells. The following image shows a Warthin tumor. 

Related Pearl: Salivary gland tumors and their frequency

  • Most (90%) of the minor salivary gland tumors are malignant, whereas parotid gland tumors (90%) are benign.
  • Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common tumor of the parotid.  It is a benign tumor.

questions.text: The tumor cells as shown in the image are seen in:
questions.solution:
The cells shown in the slide are cloverleaf or flower cells with multilobulated nuclei that are frequently observed in adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma.

Adult T-cell leukemia/ lymphoma occurs in adults infected by human T-cell leukemia retrovirus type 1 (HTLV-1). It is a neoplasm of CD4+ cells and is a rapidly progressive disease that is fatal within months to 1 year.

Common findings include skin lesions, generalized lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly and hypercalcemia.

Peripheral smear blood shows characteristic cloverleaf cells or flower cells which are tumour cells with multilobulated nuclei. Lymphocytosis is also observed.

Other options:

Mantle cell lymphoma is a type of Non-Hodgkin lymphoma in which the proliferation consists of a homogeneous population of small lymphocytes with irregular to occasionally deeply cleft (cleaved) nuclear contours. 

Peripheral T cell lymphoma is composed of malignant T cells of varied sizes with infiltration of reactive cells, such as eosinophils and macrophages. 

Anaplastic large cell lymphoma occurs due to mutation in ALK gene. It consists of large anaplastic cells with horseshoe-shaped nuclei and spacious cytoplasm (hallmark cells).

questions.text: The bodies shown in the below image are seen in ______.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a Lewy body. Lewy bodies may be found in the remaining neurons present in the substantia nigra in cases of Parkinson’s disease.

These are single or multiple, cytoplasmic, eosinophilic, round to elongated inclusions. They have a dense core, surrounded by a pale halo. On ultrastructural examination, Lewy bodies consist of fine filaments, composed of α-synuclein and other proteins, including neurofilaments and ubiquitin. The other major histologic finding is the presence of Lewy neurites that also contain aggregated α-synuclein.

The microscopic feature of Parkinson's disease is pallor of the substantia nigra and locus ceruleus. This occurs due to the loss of pigmented, catecholaminergic neurons in these regions associated with gliosis.

Other options

Option A- Pick's disease is a type of front temporal lobar degeneration. The surviving neurons show a characteristic swelling (Pick cells), and others contain Pick bodies, cytoplasmic, round to oval, filamentous inclusions that stain strongly with silver methods. 

The below image shows Pick bodies (marked with asterisks).

Option C- Microscopy of Huntington's disease shows loss of striatal neurons in the caudate nucleus, especially in the tail and in portions nearer the ventricle.

Option D- Important microscopic features of Alzheimer's disease are neuritic plaques and neurofibrillary tangles. Neuritic plaques are focal collections of dilated, tortuous axons and dendritic processes. They are present around an amyloid core. Neurofibrillary tangles are tau-containing bundles of filaments in the cytoplasm of the neurons. They can be elongated, flame-shaped, or may be rounded. (globose tangles)

The below image on the right top shows neuritic plaques and on the left bottom shows the presence of neurofibrillary tangles.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman was diagnosed with Burkitt lymphoma. Cytogenetic studies demonstrated a t (8;14) chromosomal translocation. Which of the following best explains the role of this translocation in the pathogenesis of Burkitt lymphoma in this patient?
questions.solution:
The activation of the proto-oncogene MYC due to translocation is mainly responsible for the pathogenesis of Burkitt lymphoma.

In Burkitt lymphoma, the MYC gene is translocated from its normal locus 8q24 to chromosome 14q32. The MYC gene at its normal locus is controlled and expressed in actively dividing cells. When the MYC gene is moved to 14q32, it is usually placed close to the immunoglobulin heavy chain (IGH) gene. This movement is associated with the loss of regulatory sequences of the MYC gene, which are replaced by the control regions of the IGH gene, which is highly expressed in the B cells. The translocation is denoted as t (8;14) (q24; q32).

As a result, the MYC coding sequence is intact with the loss of regulatory control. The activation of the proto-oncogene leads to overexpression of the MYC protein, which is responsible for the pathogenesis of Burkitt lymphoma.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient has complaints of painless cervical lymphadenopathy with fever, malaise, and weight loss. A lymph node was biopsied and the findings are as shown below.  All are true about the condition except

choices.text: Involves single axial group of lymph nodes

questions.solution:
The lymph node shows classical Reed-Sternberg cell seen in Hodgkin lymphoma. Mesenteric nodes are infrequently involved in Hodgkin lymphoma.

Hodgkin lymphoma is a group of lymphoid neoplasms arising in a single node and spreads from the nodes to spleen, then the liver, and finally bone marrow.

The clinical importance of this predictable route of spread is highlighted by the importance of staging which determines prognosis as well the treatment of HL.

Differences between Hodgkin and Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma

Hodgkin Lymphoma Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma
Single Axial Group of LN Multiple Peripheral lymph nodes are involved
Contiguous spread Non-contiguous spread
Mesenteric nodes and Waldeyer ring rarely involved Commonly involved
Extra nodal involvement is uncommon Common

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presented with fever, joint pain, and dyspnea. X-ray findings revealed bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. A diagnosis of sarcoidosis was made and further biopsy of the lesions was sent for histopathology. Which of the following will not be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Birbeck bodies are tennis racket–like appearing pentalaminar tubules that are associated with Langerhan cell histiocytosis and will not be seen in sarcoidosis. 

Sarcoidosis is a granulomatous disease involving multiple systems occurring due to disordered immune regulation. The diagnostic histopathologic feature of sarcoidosis, irrespective of the organ involved, is the non-caseating granuloma. Other organs involved in the disease process are: 

  • skin that shows subcutaneous nodules and erythema nodosum (painful lesions on the shin)
  • lungs that show non-cavitated consolidations 
  • lymph nodes that show hilar lymphadenopathy
  • eyes that show iridocyclitis and sicca syndrome

The other microscopic features that are seen include: 

  • Schaumann bodies: Inclusion bodies with concentric rings of calcification
  • Asteroid bodies: Stellate inclusions found within the giant cells

questions.text:
Which of the following is correct regarding Peutz-Jeghers Syndrome?

1. Arborizing pattern of connective tissue
2. Mutation in the STK11 gene
3. Multiple hamartomatous polyps
4. Autosomal recessive
5. Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium
questions.solution:
The correct statements regarding Peutz-Jeghers syndrome are 1, 2, and 3.

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is an autosomal dominant, hereditary disorder characterized by multiple gastrointestinal hamartomatous polyps and mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation. The pigmentation is particularly evident on the face, buccal mucosa, hands, feet, and perianal and genital regions. This rare syndrome presents at a median age of 11 years.

Germline heterozygous loss-of-function mutations in the gene STK11 are present in half the individuals with familial Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

Histologic examination shows a characteristic arborizing network of connective tissue, smooth muscle, lamina propria, and glands lined by the normal-appearing intestinal epithelium.

A complication of Peutz-Jeghers polyps is intussusception, which is occasionally fatal. Peutz-Jegher syndrome is associated with a markedly increased risk of colon, pancreatic, breast, lung, ovarian, and uterine cancers.

Note:- Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium is seen in FAP, not Peutz-Jeghers syndrome

Related Pearl: Peutz–Jeghers Syndrome

  • Autosomal-dominant disease
  • Germline defects in the tumor suppressor serine-threonine kinase 11 (STK11) gene on chromosome 19.

Features:

  • Hyperpigmentation of the buccal mucosa, lips, and digits
  • Hamartomatous polyps of the intestinal tract
  • Increased (2% to 10%) risk for cancer of the intestinal tract (stomach - rectum).
  • Increased risk for extraintestinal malig­nant neoplasms, including cancer of the breast, ovary, cervix, fallopian tubes, thyroid, lung, gallbladder, bile ducts, pancreas, and testicles.

Screening: Baseline colonoscopy and upper endoscopy at age 20 years, followed by annual flexible sigmoidoscopy thereafter.

 

Histologic image showing the characteristic arborizing network of connective tissue, smooth muscle, lamina propria, and glands lined by normal-appearing intestinal epithelium:

questions.text: A 55-year-old man who presented with diarrhea and flushing was found to have an ileal tumor. The histological image of the resected specimen is given below. Which of the following markers will these cells be positive for?
questions.solution:
The given history and histological image are diagnostic of ileal carcinoid. The tumor cells are typically positive for synaptophysin on immunohistochemistry.

Histology of carcinoid typically reveals islands and nests of uniform cells with scant, pink granular cytoplasm and salt and pepper chromatin. Electron microscopy reveals cytoplasmic dense-core neurosecretory granules.

Carcinoid tumors most commonly occur in the gastrointestinal tract. The most common sites in decreasing order of frequency are the appendix, ileum, and rectum. These tumors may cause carcinoid syndrome, which is characterized by cutaneous flushing, sweating, bronchospasm, colicky abdominal pain, diarrhea, and right-sided cardiac valvular fibrosis.

Immunohistochemical (IHC) markers for carcinoid tumors are:

  • Neuron-specific enolase
  • Synaptophysin
  • Chromogranin A
  • Leu 7

Related Pearl: Carcinoid syndrome

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with lower abdominal pain, which is worse during menstruation. Laparoscopic examination of the pelvis demonstrates multiple small brown spots on the surface of pelvic structures and extensive fibrous adhesions between tubes, ovaries, and other structures. A biopsy is done and microscopy is as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Microscopy shows glands resembling endometrial glands surrounded by endometrial stroma in the ovary. The most likely diagnosis is endometriosis. 

Endometriosis is defined by the presence of ectopic endometrial tissue at a site outside of the uterus. Includes both endometrial glands and stroma, but may consist only of stroma in some cases. 

It occurs in the following sites, in descending order of frequency

  • Ovaries
  • Uterine ligaments
  • Rectovaginal septum
  • Cul de sac
  • Pelvic peritoneum
  • Large and small bowel and appendix
  • Mucosa of the cervix, vagina, and fallopian tubes
  • Laparotomy scars.

It is principally a disease of women in active reproductive life, most often in the third and fourth decades. It causes infertility, dysmenorrhea (painful menstruation), pelvic pain, and other problems. Endometriotic lesions bleed periodically in response to both extrinsic cyclic (ovarian) and intrinsic hormonal stimulation.

The diagnosis is readily made when both endometrial glands and stroma are present with or without the presence of hemosiderin. In rare cases, only the stroma is identified.

Atypical endometriosis, the likely precursor to endometriosis-related ovarian carcinoma, has two morphologic appearances. One consists of cytologic atypia of the epithelium lining the endometriotic cyst without major architectural changes. The second is marked by glandular crowding due to excessive epithelial proliferation, often associated with cytologic atypia, producing an appearance that resembles complex atypical endometrial hyperplasia.

Other options

Option A- Adenomyosis is characterized by foci of the endometrium deep in the myometrium.

Option B- Chronic endometritis is a chronic inflammation of the endometrium.

Option C- Metastatic endometrial carcinoma would be characterized by abnormal glands and cytologic atypia.

questions.text: A patient who was started on penicillamine subsequently presented with facial swelling. Urinalysis shows proteinuria. Histological image of the kidney biopsy is shown below. What will be the finding on immunofluorescence?

choices.text: Granular deposits of IgG along the basement membrane
Deposition of IgA in mesangial regions

questions.solution:
The above histological image shows the presence of uniform, diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall. This image along with the clinical scenario of nephrotic syndrome depicts membranous nephropathy. Immunofluorescence, in this case, will show granular deposits of IgG along the basement membrane. 

Almost 75% of membranous nephropathy is primary and the rest is due to

  • Drugs such as penicillamine, captopril, gold, and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)
  • Malignant tumors of the lung and colon
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
  • Infections such as chronic hepatitis B, hepatitis C, syphilis
  • Autoimmune disorders such as thyroiditis

Other options:

Option B: Linear deposition of antibodies(IgG) is seen in anti-GBM antibody disease.

Option C: Deposition of IgA in mesangial regions is seen in IgA nephropathy.

Option D: Effacement of the foot process is found in the electron microscopy picture of membranous nephropathy and minimal change disease.

questions.text: Histology of reperfused myocardium:
questions.solution:
Reperfused myocardium shows eosinophilic contraction bands on light microscopy. They occur in irreversibly injured myocytes with damaged membranes, when blood supply is restored 12-24 hours after MI.

During ischemia, the intracellular levels of calcium are increased due to impaired calcium cycling and sarcolemmal damage. This leads to augmented and uncontrolled contraction of myofibrils after reperfusion. 

On microscopic examination, the irreversibly injured myocytes exhibit contraction bands that are intensely eosinophilic intracellular stripes. These contraction bands are composed of closely packed sarcomeres.

Reperfused infarcts are usually hemorrhagic because the vasculature is injured during ischemia. This leads to bleeding after the flow is restored.

questions.text: The autopsy of a 14-year-old boy who died in a motor vehicle accident showed the following lesions on the inner surface of the aorta. What do these lesions indicate?
questions.solution:
The above image shows yellow spots on the inner surface of the aorta, which represent fatty streaks. They indicate a collection of foamy macrophages in the intima of the vessel wall. 

Fatty streaks may be present in the aorta of infants, virtually all adolescents, and even individuals without known risk factors. These lesions are not indicative of atherosclerosis, but some of them may evolve into atheromatous plaques later in life by smooth muscle proliferation and extracellular matrix deposition.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man presents with painless generalized lymphadenopathy and weakness. The biopsy findings of H&E staining and immunohistochemistry for BCL2 are given in the images below. The results of immunophenotyping of the cells are as follows: CD19+, CD20+, CD10+, and CD5-. What is the translocation seen in this disease?

H&E: Hematoxyline and eosin
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of follicular lymphoma. The majority of follicular lymphomas have the characteristic t(14;18) translocation.

Follicular lymphoma presents in middle age with no sex predilection. The most common presenting symptom is painless generalized lymphadenopathy. A lymph node biopsy is adequate for the diagnosis of follicular lymphoma. Immunophenotyping of the cells showing CD19, CD20, CD10, BCL2 positive, and CD5 negative is suggestive that the cells originate from the germinal center.

This chromosomal rearrangement results in the overexpression of BCL2 protein, which is an inhibitor of apoptosis that contributes to cell survival.

On histopathology, the lymph nodes exhibit a nodular or nodular and diffuse growth pattern. Two cell types are predominantly present in varying proportions: 

  • Centrocytes (small cleaved cells) - small cells with a cleaved nucleus and scant cytoplasm
  • Centroblasts - large cells with open nuclear chromatin, several nucleoli, and modest amounts of cytoplasm

In most cases, there is a majority of centrocytes.

Other options:

Option B: t(9;22) results in Philadelphia chromosome, which causes chronic myeloid leukemia.

Option C: t(8;14) is seen in Burkitt lymphoma.

Option D: t(11,14) is seen in mantle cell lymphoma.

questions.text: A young man who had severe anemia underwent a blood transfusion with packed red blood cells. One hour later he appeared pale and developed fever with chills, flank pain, and dark-colored urine. A direct Coombs test was positive. Which of the following is implicated in this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
Type II hypersensitivity reaction is implicated in this patient presenting with acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR) following blood transfusion. It occurs most often due to ABO incompatibility and commonly occurs due to negligence in patient identification or tube labeling.

Type II hypersensitivity reaction is antibody-mediated. In ABO incompatibility, preformed IgM antibodies attack the antigens on donor red cells which causes complement fixation. This results in complement-mediated lysis, intravascular hemolysis, and hemoglobinuria. Complement activation produces fever with shaking chills. The patient appears pale due to hemolysis and has acute flank pain with dark-colored urine (hemoglobinuria).

The direct Coombs test is usually positive. Direct Coombs test/antiglobulin test is done on the surface of red blood cells. The Coombs reagent consists of anti-human antibodies. On combining with the red blood cells, the test becomes positive, if there are RBC antibodies present in the sample. This is because the anti-human antibodies in the reagent bind with the human antibodies in the RBCs and form a link. 

Other options:

Option A: Type I hypersensitivity reaction is IgE mediated. An anaphylactic blood transfusion reaction is a type I hypersensitivity reaction. However, it presents within seconds to minutes of blood transfusion with hypotension, urticaria, angioedema, and wheezing.

Option C: Type III hypersensitivity reaction, also known as immune complex-mediated hypersensitivity reaction, occurs when antigen-antibody complexes deposition leads to complement activation. Examples include SLE, serum sickness, and the Arthus reaction.

Option D: Type IV hypersensitivity , also known as a cell-mediated or delayed hypersensitivity reaction, is caused by activated T lymphocytes. Examples include contact dermatitis and tuberculin skin testing.

Related Pearl: Blood Transfusion Reactions

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient presents with anemia. His father and paternal aunt had a similar illness that was treated successfully by splenectomy. His peripheral blood smear is similar to that shown in the illustration below. Which of the following additional abnormalities is expected?
questions.solution:
The given image shows spherocytes on the peripheral blood smear. A history of anemia along with a family history of splenectomy strongly suggest a diagnosis of hereditary spherocytosis. The presence of Howell-Jolly bodies is an additional abnormality that can be expected here.

Hereditary spherocytosis is an autosomal dominant disorder. It is due to defects in ankyrin, band 3, spectrin, or band 4.2 proteins, leading to a defect in the red cell membrane that causes red cells to transform into spherocytes.

The patients usually present with anemia, gallstones, splenomegaly, and jaundice. Aplastic crisis might occur due to parvovirus infection. 

Spherocytosis is the common finding, which presents as small, dark-staining (hyperchromic) red cells without the central zone of pallor. Other features are increased reticulocyte count, Howell-Jolly bodies which are dense basophilic nuclear remnants in the RBCs, marrow erythroid hyperplasia, and hemosiderosis. 

Laboratory findings are increased normal or slight decrease in mean corpuscular volume (MCV), increased mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC >34), and increased red cell distribution width (RDW >14%).

Increased osmotic fragility is seen in the majority of the cases. 

Heinz bodies are denatured precipitates that cause damage to the RBC membrane. These cells passing through splenic cords get the characteristic appearance of bite cells. They are seen in cases of chemical poisoning, drug toxicity, and glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency. 

The image below shows Heinz bodies and bite cells.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child abruptly develops malaise, fever, nausea, oliguria, and smoky, cola-colored urine 2 weeks after recovery from a sore throat. He is found to have periorbital edema and mild hypertension. Urine examination shows dysmorphic red cells and red cell casts in the urine with mild proteinuria. Which type of hypersensitivity is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of nephritic syndrome due to post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis. This is an example of a type III hypersensitivity reaction.

In type III hypersensitivity, immune complexes may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement. The pathogenesis of systemic immune complex disease can be divided into three phases:

  • Formation of immune complexes
  • Deposition of immune complexes
  • Inflammation and tissue injury

This results in various manifestations like vasculitis, glomerulonephritis and arthritis.

Examples of type III hypersensitivity reactions:

  • Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Reactive arthritis
  • Polyarteritis nodosa
  • Serum sickness
  • Arthus reaction
  • Farmer’s lung
  • Hypersensitivity pneumonitis
  • Type II lepra reaction
  • Henoch–Schonlein purpura

The image given below shows the mechanism of type III hypersensitivity reactions.

questions.text: A 51-year-old male patient who is a chronic smoker presents with dry persistent cough and progressive dyspnea. You are suspecting small cell carcinoma of lung. Which of the following tumor markers is likely to be elevated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of small cell carcinoma of the lung (SCLC) in which levels of neuron-specific enolase (NSE) are elevated.

NSE is also called gamma enolase or enolase 2 (ENO2) and is encoded by ENO2 gene. It is a phosphopyruvate hydratase that is produced by small-cell lung carcinomas, which are neuroendocrine in origin. Their levels have been implicated as a prognostic factor for patients with small-cell lung cancer.

questions.text: An autopsy is done on a plastic factory worker. The gross specimen of the liver is shown in the image below. Reddish-brown hemorrhagic foci and several blood-filled spaces (arrows) are present. The asterisk marks the normal liver tissue. Which of the following compounds is most likely to have played a role in the pathogenesis of the involved tumor?
questions.solution:
The gross specimen of the liver shows greyish-white lesions, with multiple reddish-brown hemorrhagic foci and several blood-filled spaces (arrows) which are seen with hepatic angiosarcoma. Exposure to polyvinyl chloride, arsenic, and thorotrast can lead to this condition.

Angiosarcoma is a malignant endothelial neoplasm that has equal gender predilection. The tumor may occur at any site, but most often involves skin, soft tissue, breast, and liver. They are locally invasive and can readily metastasize.

Hepatic angiosarcomas are associated with exposure to carcinogens.

Examples of carcinogenic agents:

  • Arsenic - in pesticides
  • Thorotrast - a radioactive contrast agent formerly used for radiologic imaging
  • Polyvinyl chloride - a widely used plastic

Hepatic tumors and associated agents

Carcinoma

Carcinogens

Oral contraceptives, anabolic steroids

Hepatocellular carcinoma 

Alcohol, thorotrast

Cholangiocarcinoma

Thorotrast

Angiosarcoma

Thorotrast, vinyl chloride, Arsenic

The given histopathological image shows abundant small blood vessels lined by large atypical endothelial cells and atypical mitoses seen in angiosarcoma. The endothelial origin of these tumors can be demonstrated by immunohistochemical staining for CD31 or von Willebrand factor.

questions.text: An 82-year-old male patient dies of severe congestive heart failure. An autopsy was done, which revealed the following appearance of the aortic valve. Blood investigations done before death revealed normal levels of serum sodium, potassium, calcium, and chloride. Which of the following pathological processes is likely to have resulted in the appearance of the aortic valve as shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The image shows extensive calcification of the aortic valve resulting in stenosis. Calcification of the valve, in an elderly patient, with normal serum calcium levels, occurs due to dystrophic calcification.

When the deposition of calcium occurs in dead or dying tissues, it is called dystrophic calcification. This occurs in the absence of derangements in calcium metabolism, i.e. the calcium levels are normal. Dystrophic calcification is seen in areas of necrosis of any type including coagulative, caseous, or liquefactive, and in foci of enzymatic fat necrosis.

Some examples include atheromas of advanced atherosclerosis and areas of caseous necrosis in tuberculosis. It also commonly develops in aging or damaged heart valves.

Other options:

Option A - Cardiac amyloidosis may occur secondary to systemic amyloidosis or as a result of aging (senile amyloidosis). It is associated with the deposition of hyaline, eosinophilic amyloid, in the conduction tissue, interstitium, and coronary vessels. These deposits may be seen on Congo red staining.

Option B - Monckeberg medial sclerosis is a vascular pathology of aging characterized by calcifications accumulating in the medial layers of muscular arteries. Since there is no vascular compromise (no luminal narrowing), it is usually an accidental finding.

Option D - Metastatic calcification occurs in normal tissues, in the presence of hypercalcemia. It is usually a consequence of excessive parathyroid hormone.

Related Pearl: Types of calcifications

vitamin D intoxication

questions.text: Revised Ghent criteria takes into account all of the following except___________

choices.text: Cardinal clinical signs in absence of family history
Presence or absence of fibrillin mutation

questions.solution:
Revised Ghent criteria does not take into account the presence of defective collagen synthesis.

Clinical diagnosis of Marfan syndrome is currently based on the revised Ghent criteria which takes into account:

  • Family history
  • Cardinal clinical signs in absence of family history
  • Presence or absence of fibrillin mutation

In general major involvement of two major organ systems (skeletal, cardiovascular, ocular and skin) and minor involvement of another organ is required for diagnosis.

Marfan’s syndrome: It is an autosomal dominant connective tissue disorder.

  • This autosomal dominant syndrome has pleiotropic manifestations involving primarily the ocular, cardiovascular, and skeletal systems.
  • Occurs due to a missense mutation in the fibrillin-1 gene located on chromosome 15 at band q21.1 (15q21.1).

Morphological features:

  1. Skeletal abnormalities:
    1. Typically the patient is unusually tall with exceptionally long extremities and long, tapering fingers and toes.
    2. Hyperextensibility due to laxity of joint ligaments.
    3. The head is commonly dolichocephalic (long-headed).
    4. A variety of spinal deformities may appear, including kyphosis, scoliosis, or rotation or slipping of the dorsal or lumbar vertebrae.
    5. The chest is classically deformed, presenting either pectus excavatum (deeply depressed sternum) or a pigeon-breast deformity.
  2. Ocular changes:
    1. Most characteristic is bilateral subluxation or dislocation (usually outward and upward) of the lens, referred to as ectopia lentis.
  3. Cardiovascular lesions:
    1. Most life-threatening features of this disorder. The two most common lesions are mitral valve prolapse and, of greater importance, dilation of the ascending aorta due to cystic medial necrosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding necroptosis?

choices.text: Kinases like RIP1 and RIP3 are involved
It causes caspase-independent programmed cell death
Cytokine IL-1 plays an important role in the process
Necroptosis starts by ligation of TNFR1

questions.solution:
The fever-inducing cytokine IL-1 plays an important role in pyroptosis and not necroptosis. 

Necroptosis, also known as programmed necrosis, is programmed cell death without caspase activation. It shares features of both necrosis and apoptosis.

It resembles necrosis because of the following features:

  • loss of ATP
  • swelling of the cell and organelles
  • generation of reactive oxygen species (ROS)
  • release of lysosomal enzymes
  • rupture of the plasma membrane

It is triggered by genetically programmed signal transduction events that lead to cell death. This resembles programmed cell death, which is considered the hallmark of apoptosis. Hence, necroptosis is also called programmed necrosis.

Necroptosis does not result in caspase activation, and hence, it is also called “caspase-independent” programmed cell death (option B). The process starts with the ligation of TNFR1 (option D). Ligation of TNFR1 recruits two kinases called receptor-associated kinases 1 and 3 (RIP1 & RIP3) (option A).

Necroptosis begins similarly to the extrinsic pathway of apoptosis, i.e., by receptor-ligand interaction. The most well-studied is the TNF-TNFR mediated pathway. The pathway is demonstrated below:

Pyroptosis is a process of cell death that is different from apoptosis and necrosis. It is involved in the clearance of necrotic and infected cells. This type of programmed cell death is dependent on caspase 1. Caspases 4 and 5 are also involved and cause the death of infected cells. The pathway involves:

Cells infected by microbes → activation of inflammasome complex → activation of the caspase-1 → generation of biologically active IL-1 → fever, inflammation, leukocyte recruitment.

questions.text: An older patient with bilateral hearing loss and occasional vertigo is being investigated. Biopsy from the region is given below. The most likely diagnosis is _____.
questions.solution:
The given histology image shows dense pink Antoni A areas predominantly (bottom left) and loose, pale Antoni B areas (top right), as well as hyalinized blood vessels seen in schwannoma.

Schwannomas are benign tumors that exhibit Schwann cell differentiation and often arise directly from peripheral nerves. They are associated with inactivating mutations in the NF2 (Neurofibromatosis 2) gene on chromosome 22.

They appear as well-circumscribed, encapsulated masses that are attached loosely to the associated nerve without invading. They cause symptoms by local compression of the involved nerve or adjacent structures.

Their cell of origin is the Schwann cell, thus they show immunoreactivity for the S-100 marker.

Treatment is done using surgical removal.

Other options:

Option A: Leiomyomas are benign smooth muscle tumors, that often arise in the uterus and are the most common neoplasm in women. Histologically, they are composed of fascicles of densely eosinophilic spindle cells that tend to intersect each other at right angles. 

Option B: Rhabdomyomas are the most frequent primary tumors of the heart in children. Microscopically, they are composed of bizarre, markedly enlarged myocytes with abundant glycogen. But due to routine histological processing, the glycogen content is reduced and looks like thin strands that stretch from the nuclei to the surface membrane, which appears like ‘spider cells’.

Option D: Neurofibromas are also benign nerve sheath tumors and the histological picture shows the presence of bland Schwann cells admixed with stromal cells such as mast cells, perineural cells, and fibroblasts. The stroma of the tumors contains loose collagen arranged in wavy bundles.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old female patient has come to the medicine OPD with complaints of fatigue for the past 3 months. She has an 8-year-old son and there is no history of any chronic illness. She has been on the oral contraceptive pill for the past year. Peripheral smear findings are as given below.

Her laboratory investigations show:

  • Hb - 5.3gm%
  • TLC - 1100cells/mm3
  • MCV - 102fl
  • MCH - 40 pg
  • MCHC - 32g/dL

Which among the following is not a bone marrow finding of the above condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a female consuming oral contraceptive pills presenting with fatigue, laboratory values showing anemia, increased MCV and MCH, normal MCHC, and the peripheral smear showing Howell-jolly bodies, basophilic stippling, and hypersegmented neutrophils are suggestive of megaloblastic anemia. Megaloblasts in the bone marrow will show a nucleus with prominent nucleoli and a fine nuclear chromatin pattern. Pyknotic nuclei in megaloblasts is not a bone marrow finding in this condition.

Megaloblastic anemia:  There is impairment of DNA synthesis that leads to ineffective hematopoiesis and distinctive morphologic changes, including abnormally large erythroid precursors and red cells.

The cause of megaloblastic anemia is either Vitamin B12 deficiency or folic acid deficiency. Both can occur as a result of impaired absorption or inadequate intake. Oral contraceptives may impair the absorption of folic acid.

The peripheral smear will show:

  • Macro-ovalocytes with aniso and poikilocytosis.
  • Most macrocytes lack the central pallor of normal red cells and even appear hyperchromic, but the MCHC is not elevated.
  • The reticulocyte count is low.
  • Nucleated red cell progenitors occasionally appear in the circulating blood when anemia is severe.
  • Neutrophils are also larger than normal (macro polymorphonuclear) and show nuclear hypersegmentation, having five or more nuclear lobules.

The following image shows the peripheral blood smear findings in megaloblastic anemia.

Bone Marrow:

  • Markedly hypercellular as a result of increased hematopoietic precursors.
  • Large hematopoietic precursors- megaloblasts.
  • Since the nuclear maturation is delayed, the precursors retain fine nuclear chromatin instead of having clumped pyknotic nucleus.
  • The hemoglobin accumulation in the cytoplasm is normal, while the nuclear maturation is delayed. This leads to nuclear-to-cytoplasmic asynchrony. 
  • Granulocytic precursors also display dysmaturation in the form of giant metamyelocytes and band forms.
  • Megakaryocytes, too, can be abnormally large and have bizarre, multilobate nuclei.
  • The derangement in DNA synthesis causes most precursors to undergo apoptosis in the marrow (ineffective hematopoiesis) and leads to pancytopenia.

questions.text: You are posted in pediatrics OPD as an intern. A 7-year-old child presents to the clinic with a history of recurrent fractures and poorly-developed teeth. Examination reveals joint laxity and blue sclera. Both parents are phenotypically normal. Your senior asks you to interpret the mode of inheritance in this case from the pedigree chart given below.
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of recurrent fractures, poorly developed teeth with blue sclera, and joint laxity is suggestive of osteogenesis imperfecta. Osteogenesis imperfecta is an example of gonadal mosaicism where phenotypically normal parents can have more than one affected child.

It is a type of autosomal dominant disorder where some patients do not have phenotypically affected parents. The disorder can result from a new mutation in the egg or the sperm from which the zygote was formed. The siblings may or may not be affected. In some cases, mosaicism can result from a mutation that occurs after the formation of the zygote, during early (embryonic) development.

A phenotypically normal parent who has gonadal mosaicism can transmit the disease-causing mutation to the offspring through their mutated ova/sperm. Therefore, there is a possibility that more than one child of such a parent can be affected.

Other options:

Option A- In X-linked recessive conditions, an affected male does not transmit the disorder to his sons but all daughters will be carriers of the disease. Sons of heterozygous women have a chance of inheriting the mutant gene.

Option B- In mitochondrial inheritance, if the mother is affected and the father is normal, then all their children (both male and female) will be affected. However, children born to an affected father and a normal mother will not be affected.

Option C- Genomic imprinting is the transcriptional silencing of either maternal or paternal allele. Prader-Willi syndrome is paternal imprinting (deletion of paternal chromosome15 in 65-75% of individuals), maternal uniparental disomy 15 (20-30%), or an imprinting defect; and Angelman syndrome is due to maternal imprinting (deletion of maternal chromosome 15).

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman coming from a hilly area presents with a hard swelling in the neck which moves up with deglutition and does not move with protrusion of the tongue. The biopsy of the frozen section is given below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the given histopathological image showing uniform sheets of cells with capsular invasion by tumor cells is suggestive of follicular carcinoma thyroid.

The following images show follicular carcinoma of the thyroid.

Option A: In follicular adenoma, there is no capsular invasion.

Option C: Anaplastic carcinoma is associated with rapidly progressive swelling with obstructive features and undifferentiated cells on histopathology.

Option D: In medullary carcinoma, amyloid stroma is seen on histopathology.

Related Pearl: Follicular thyroid malignancy

It is more common in iodine-deficient areas. It is associated with p53, PTEN, PAX/PPAR-gamma, RAS, miRNA (miR-197 and miR-346).

It commonly presents as solitary thyroid nodules and the mean age of presentation is 50 years. It can also occur in long-standing cases of multinodular goitre.

FNAC is unable to distinguish between benign and malignant follicular lesions as malignancy is defined by capsular and vascular invasion. Hence, Trucut biopsy is required to confirm malignancy.

Histological findings:

  • Encapsulated
  • Uniform microfollicles or sheets of cells devoid of colloid
  • Capsular and vascular invasion indicates malignancy
  • Tumour thrombus within middle thyroid/ jugular veins may be seen at the time of surgery

Vascular (hematogenous) dissemination is common, with metastases to bone, lungs, liver, and elsewhere. The prognosis depends largely on the extent of invasion and stage at presentation.

Serum thyroglobulin levels are used for monitoring tumour recurrence, as they are undetectable after complete treatment.

questions.text: A retired 65-year-old man was found to have a mass in the right lower lobe of the lung on chest x-ray. A  biopsy sample was taken from the mass. The image below shows the findings of histopathological examination and Immunohistochemical staining with calretinin. Which of the following was the most likely profession of the patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the image showing malignant epithelioid mesothelioma (a neoplasm most commonly associated with asbestos exposure) is most likely suggestive of asbestosis. Hence, the most likely profession of this patient would be an asbestos factory worker.

The histopathological image shows cuboidal and flattened cells forming tubular or papillary structures resembling adenocarcinoma. These are strongly positive for calretinin. These features point toward the diagnosis of malignant epithelioid mesothelioma. The most common cancer associated with asbestosis is lung adenocarcinoma; however, mesothelioma is the most specific malignancy.

Malignant mesothelioma is a rare and aggressive malignant tumor of the pleura, associated with heavy asbestos exposure. It arises from either the visceral or parietal pleura. Less common sites include the peritoneum, pericardium, tunica vaginalis, and genital tract. 

Clinical features include chest pain, dyspnea, and recurrent pleural effusions. The lung is invaded directly, and metastatic spread may involve the hilar lymph nodes, the liver, and other distant organs. 

Grossly, it appears as a diffuse lesion arising either from the visceral or parietal pleura. The affected lung is ensheathed by a thick layer of soft, gelatinous, greyish-pink tumor tissue.

The image given below shows the gross pathology of mesothelioma:

Microscopically, they are of three types:

  • Epithelial - shows cuboidal, columnar, or flattened cells forming tubular or papillary structures resembling adenocarcinoma
  • Sarcomatous/mesenchymal- has a histological appearance resembling fibrosarcoma
  • Biphasic/mixed

The image given below shows an epithelioid type of mesothelioma showing cuboidal, columnar, or flattened cells forming tubular or papillary structures resembling adenocarcinoma.

The image given below shows malignant mesothelioma under immunohistochemical staining with calretinin.

Other options :

Option B: Sandblasters are at increased risk of developing silicosis. Silicosis is associated with the calcification of hilar lymph nodes, which leads to the appearance of eggshell calcification. Histopathology in silicosis shows whorled collagen fibers. HRCT in patients with silicosis shows a characteristic crazy paving pattern.

The image below shows whorled collagen in a silicosis nodule:

 

Option C: Welders are at increased risk of exposure to iron oxide, leading to siderosis.

 

Option D: Coal miners are at increased risk of developing coal workers' pneumoconiosis.  

The image below shows histopathological appearance of coal worker's pneumoconiosis:

questions.text:
A 70-year-old male patient is found to have a hard, irregular nodule within his prostate on rectal examination. A biopsy of this lesion and immunohistochemistry confirms the diagnosis of carcinoma of the prostate. If the carcinoma has metastasized, which of the following bones are affected in the decreasing order of frequency?
  1. Thoracic spine
  2. Proximal femur
  3. Pelvis
  4. Lumbar spine
questions.solution:
Carcinoma prostate spreads via the hematogenous route predominantly to the lumbar spine > proximal femur > pelvis > thoracic spine > ribs (Option A- 4,2,3,1) in decreasing order of frequency. These bony metastases are typically osteoblastic lesions.

Carcinoma of the prostate:

It is the most common malignant tumor in men over the age of 65 years  They may range from indolent lesions that cause no harm to aggressive metastatic tumors. Most cancers are clinically silent and are detected on routine rectal examination or PSA measurements.

Grossly, malignant tissue is gritty and firm in consistency (in contrast to the spongy appearance of benign tissue) and thus more readily palpable on digital rectal examination. They usually arise in the peripheral zone of the gland.

Prostate carcinoma is a type of adenocarcinoma. Therefore, histopathology shows the malignant cells arranged in the form of glands. In contrast to benign glands, malignant glands have tightly packed cells and characteristically lack branching and papillary infoldings. The outer basal cell layer typical of benign glands is absent. The cells may show increased nuclear-cytoplasmic ratio, nuclear atypia, etc. α-methyl acyl-coenzyme A-racemase (AMACR) is positive and is upregulated in prostate cancer.

Local extension most commonly involves the periprostatic tissue, seminal vesicles, and the base of the urinary bladder. Advanced disease may produce ureteral obstruction. Metastasis spreads via the lymphatics to the obturator nodes and the para-aortic nodes. Hematogenous spread occurs chiefly through the bones to the axial skeleton and rarely to the viscera. The bony metastasis is blastic in origin and involves the lumbar spine, proximal femur, pelvis, thoracic spine, and ribs in the decreasing order of frequency. 

Prognosis and staging: The Gleason grading system correlates with the pathological stage, spread, and prognosis. Measurement of serum PSA levels may be useful to assist with the diagnosis and management.

Below image shows histopathology of Prostate carcinoma

Related Pearl: Types of metastasis(osteoblastic or osteolytic) and their primary:

Predominantly osteoblastic:

  • Prostate cancer
  • Osteosarcoma 
  • Medullary carcinoma thyroid

Mixed osteoblastic and osteolytic:

  • Breast cancer(preponderance toward osteolytic)
  • Lymphoma
  • Urothelial carcinoma 
  • Lung cancer

Predominantly osteolytic:

  • Renal cell carcinoma
  • Multiple myeloma 
  • Thyroid carcinoma(except medullary carcinoma thyroid)
  • Gastrointestinal tract carcinoma
  • Malignant melanoma

questions.text: A 60 year-old-woman comes with complaints of sudden onset blindness of the right eye, with throbbing headache in the right temporal region associated with jaw claudication. On examination, a thickened tender cord-like structure can be felt in the temple. Temporal artery biopsy shows the following. Which among the following is true about this condition?

choices.text: Lesions are distributed throughout the entire length of the artery
Classic lesions exhibit medial granulomatous inflammation
T cell infiltrates are predominantly CD8+
Fragmentation is seen in external elastic lamina

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and histology image is suggestive of giant cell/temporal arteritis. Classic lesions exhibit medial granulomatous inflammation.

Giant cell/temporal arteritis is a chronic inflammatory disorder of large to small-sized arteries that especially affects the arteries of the head. It is seen in people over 50 years of age.

It can affect the following arteries:

  • Superficial temporal artery: Intense facial pain or headache along the course of the artery
  • Ophthalmic arteries: Sudden and permanent diplopia or blindness
  • Aorta: Giant-cell aortitis
  • Vertebral arteries

A biopsy is needed to confirm the diagnosis. However, a negative biopsy cannot exclude the diagnosis of giant cell arteritis because the lesions are focally distributed, leaving long segments of the artery normal. Hence, the biopsy sample may be taken from the normal part of the artery, leading to a false-negative report. For the same reason, an adequate biopsy requires at least a 1-cm segment.

Biopsy findings of giant cell arteritis include:

  • Classic lesions are primarily medial granulomatous inflammation.
  • These lesions involve the internal elastic lamina, leading to elastic lamina fragmentation.
  • There is intimal thickening that reduces the luminal diameter.
  • There is an infiltrate with T cells (CD4+ > CD8+), macrophages, and multinucleated giant cells (75% of specimens).

The image below shows giant cell arteritis with intimal thickening and internal elastic lamina fragmentation:

 

Corticosteroids and anti-TNF therapies are used for treatment.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy with fever and weight loss came to the hospital. On examination, he was pale and had significant lymphadenopathy. The bone marrow histology of the person is as given below. Which of the following signifies a bad prognosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the bone marrow histology suggest a diagnosis of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), where peripheral blast counts of >100,000 is a poor prognostic factor.

Acute lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphomas (ALL) are neoplasms composed of immature B (pre-B) or T (pre-T) cells referred to as lymphoblasts. About 85% are B-cell ALLs which present as childhood leukemias and T-ALLs are usually seen in adolescent boys with thymic involvement.

Clinical Features:

  • Abrupt stormy onset within days to a few weeks of the first symptoms.
  • Symptoms related to depression of marrow function include anemia and fever,
  • Secondary infections due to neutropenia and bleeding due to thrombocytopenia
  • Mass effects caused by neoplastic infiltration.
  • Bone pain resulting from marrow expansion and infiltration of the subperiosteum
  • Generalized lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, and hepatomegaly
  • Testicular enlargement
  • Central nervous system manifestations such as headache, vomiting, and nerve palsies

Genetic diseases like Bloom syndrome, Fanconi anemia, and ataxia-telangiectasia predisposes to ALL.

Histopathology of ALL:

  • The marrow is hypercellular and packed with lymphoblasts. These cells replace the normal marrow.
  • Lymphoblasts have scant cytoplasm with no granulations. They are myeloperoxidase negative and contain PAS-positive cytoplasmic material.
  • The tumor cells have a basophilic cytoplasm. The nuclei of these cells are larger than the small lymphocytes. The nucleoli are usually small. The nuclear chromatin is delicate and finely stippled, and nucleoli are small and demarcated by a rim of condensed chromatin. The nuclear membrane is deeply subdivided and gives a convoluted appearance.
  • The macrophages engulfing the apoptotic tumor cells might give it a starry sky appearance as in other rapidly growing tumors.

Cytogenetics and immunophenotype:

  • Majority of the cells express TdT (terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase), a specialized DNA polymerase that is expressed only in pre-B and pre-T lymphoblasts.
  • Immature B-ALLs do not express CD10. Late pre-B-ALLs express CD10, CD19, and CD20
  • T-ALLs are positive for CD1, CD2, CD5, and CD7.
  • The more immature tumors are usually negative for CD3, CD4, and CD8, but late pre–T-cell tumors are positive for these markers.

Factors associated with a worse prognosis:

  • Age younger than 2 years
  • Presentation in adolescence or adulthood
  • Peripheral blood blast counts greater than 100,000, which probably reflects a high tumor burden.

Factors associated with good prognosis:

  • Age between 2 and 10 years
  • A low white cell count
  • Hyperdiploidy
  • Trisomy of chromosomes 4, 7, and 10
  • Presence of t(12;21)

Related Pearl: Morphological Characteristics of Blasts Cells in Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia vs. Acute Myeloid Leukemia

  Lymphoblasts  Myeloblasts 
Blast population Homogeneous Heterogeneous, with the exception of the undifferentiated form 
Size Variable, mainly small  Variable, mainly large 
Nucleus Central, mainly round; sometimes indented. 
 		 Eccentric, round, oval, or angulated; sometimes convoluted, particularly in the form with a monocytic component 
Chromatin Fine, with dispersed condensation. 
Very condensed in small lymphoblasts 		 Fine, granular, delicately dispersed 
Nucleoli Absent in small lymphoblasts. 
Sometimes indistinct 		 Present. Often large and prominent, double or triple 
Cytoplasm Scanty and basophilic.
Sometimes with a single long projection (hand-mirror cell) 		 Variable. 
Abundant in monoblasts, 
with protrusions in erythroblasts and megakaryoblasts 
Granules Rarely present. Negative for peroxidase, esterases, and toluidine blue  Present in forms with differentiation and positive with cytochemical stains
  • Peroxidase in the neutrophil and eosinophil lineages
  • Nonspecific esterase in the monocyte lineage 
Auer rods Absent  Can be present. 
Typically present in the hyper granular promyelocytic form 
Vacuoles Can be present Can be present. 
Almost always present in forms with a monocytic component 

The image given below shows lymphoblasts.

The image given below shows myeloblasts.

questions.text:
Identify the numbered structures in the given image?

A. DMT1/Divalent metal transporter 1
B. Transferrin
C. Ferroportin
D. Hepcidin
questions.solution:
The given illustration shows iron absorption in duodenal epithelial cells.

The marked structures are:

1 - D. Hepcidin

2 - C. Ferroportin

3 - B. Transferrin 

4 - A. DMT1/Divalent metal transporter 1

Iron Absorption :

Iron is mainly absorbed from the duodenum and proximal small intestine. The acidic contents of the stomach play a major role in absorption. Once it reaches the brush border of the absorbing cell, the ferric form is converted to ferrous form by ferrireductase. This ferrous form is then transported into the cell by divalent metal transporter type 1. (DMT-1)

Once inside the cell, iron may be stored as ferritin or transported to plasma through ferroportin. During the transport, iron is converted back into the ferric form by hephaestin and ceruloplasmin. The iron in plasma is then transferred to the required tissues with the help of protein transferrin. Iron is a major content of hemoglobin, myoglobin, cytochrome P-450 group of enzymes, components of electron transport chain, and ribonucleotide reductase.

Clinical significance - Iron is available in food in two forms, heme and nonheme. Heme iron is mainly present in red meat and is readily absorbed.

Iron absorption in the duodenum is mainly regulated by hepcidin. It inhibits ferroportin and suppresses the release of iron from macrophages which is used by erythroid precursors to make hemoglobin. High hepcidin levels are seen in systemic inflammation and low hepcidin levels are seen in hemochromatosis.

The following illustration shows the absorption of iron at the duodenum:

Related Pearl: Differential Diagnosis of Microcytic Anaemia

Investigation Iron- Deficiency Anemia Alpha or beta thalassemia Anemia of Chronic Disease
Serum Iron <60 µg/dL Normal/Increased Decreased
Serum Ferritin <20 µg/L Normal/Increased Increased
TIBC Increased Normal Decreased
Transferrin saturation <15% Normal Normal/Decreased
MCV Decreased  Decreased Normal/Decreased
RBC count Decreased Normal/Increased Normal/Increased

TIBC: Total iron-binding capacity

questions.text: A 27-year-old female had undergone a lower segment cesarean section. She got the skin sutures removed on the seventh postoperative day. What is the maximum percent of wound strength that can be expected after complete healing?
questions.solution:
The maximum percent of wound strength that can be expected after complete wound healing is around 80%. It does not substantially improve beyond that point.

Wound healing occurs in two distinct mechanisms - first intention/ primary union, and secondary intention/ secondary union.

Primary union is seen in cases where only the epithelial layer is injured. An example of such healing is seen in a clean surgical incision approximated by sutures.

The primary union begins with an injury that causes the activation of the coagulation cascade and subsequent clot formation. This clot attracts growth factors, cytokines, chemokines, and migrating cells. Within the first 24 hours, the neutrophils migrate to the site of injury. Within 24-48 hours, even epithelial cells from both edges of the wound begin to migrate and form a thin layer of epidermis over the wound. By day 3, neutrophils are mainly replaced by macrophages and granulation tissue starts forming. This process of neovascularisation reaches its peak on day 5. Deposition of collagen and fibroblast proliferation is seen in the second week. By the end of the first month, the scar is formed, which is made of cellular connective tissue largely devoid of inflammatory cells but covered by an essentially normal epidermis.

Wounds heal by secondary intention when the wound is large involving a more significant loss of cells and tissues. Since the wound is large, the blood clot formed is large. This leads to increased inflammation and increased formation of granulation tissue. The provisional matrix has fibrin, plasma fibronectin, and type III collagen. In two weeks, it is replaced by type I collagen. By the end of 1 month, the scar tissue, mainly made of acellular connective tissue, is formed and myofibroblasts in it cause wound contraction.

Related Pearl: Factors Influencing Healing

  • Infection: one of the most important causes of delay in healing; prolongs inflammation; increases the local tissue injury
  • Diabetes: most important systemic cause of abnormal wound healing
  • Nutritional status: protein deficiency and vitamin C deficiency inhibit collagen synthesis and retard healing.
  • Glucocorticoids (steroids): anti-inflammatory effects; results in weakness of the scar due to inhibition of TGF-β production and diminished fibrosis
  • Mechanical factors: such as increased local pressure or torsion; may cause wounds to pull apart or dehisce
  • Poor perfusion: due to arteriosclerosis, diabetes, or obstructed venous drainage; also impairs healing
  • Foreign bodies: such as fragments of steel, glass, or even bone; impede healing
  • Type and extent of tissue injury: affect subsequent repair;
  • Location of the injury and the character of the injured tissue: also important

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the group of chemokines that IL-8 belongs to?

choices.text: They are secreted by activated macrophages
They have 3 amino acids between the two cysteines

questions.solution:
IL­8 is a typical example of the CXC chemokine group. It is secreted by activated macrophages and endothelial cells.

Chemokines are a family of small proteins that act as chemoattractants for specific types of leukocytes. They are classified into four major groups, according to the arrangement of cysteine (C) residues in the proteins:

  • C-X-C chemokines have one amino acid residue separating the first two conserved cysteine residues. They are secreted by activated macrophages, endothelial cells, and other cell types. Their most important inducers are microbial products and other cytokines, mainly IL­1 and TNF. They cause activation and chemotaxis of neutrophils. IL-­8 is typical of this group. 
  • C-C chemokines have the first two conserved cysteine residues adjacent to each other. They mainly act on monocytes, eosinophils, basophils, and lymphocytes, and have fewer actions on neutrophils. Important C-C chemokines are monocyte chemoattractant protein (MCP-1), eotaxin, macrophage inflammatory protein-1α (MIP-1α), etc.
  • C chemokines lack the first and third of the four conserved cysteines. The C chemokines (e.g., lymphotactin) are relatively specific for lymphocytes.
  • CX3C chemokines contain three amino acids between the two cysteines. The only known member of this class is called fractalkine. It acts as a chemoattractant and promotes strong adhesion of monocytes and T cells.

Related Pearl: Various Types of Chemokines Based on their Structure

1.   CXC chemokines (α-chemokines): They have a total of four cysteines, of which the first two separated by one amino acid, represented by 'X'. e.g., interleukin-8 (IL-8/ CXCL8)

2. CC chemokines (β-chemokines): They have a total of four cysteines, of which the first two are adjacent near their amino terminus. e.g., CC chemokine ligands (CCL-1 to 28).

3. C chemokines (γ-chemokines): They have only two cysteines; the first and third of the four cysteines i.e. one N-terminal cysteine and one cysteine downstream. e.g., XCL1 (lymphotactin-α) and XCL2 (lymphotactin-β).

4. CX3C chemokines (d-chemokines): They have three amino acids between two cysteines e.g., fractalkine (or CX3CL1). It acts as a chemoattractant and as an adhesion molecule.

questions.text: A 4-month-old baby was brought to the OPD with stiffness and weakness of limbs which rapidly progressed resulting in the death of the baby. An autopsy was conducted where the histology of the brain parenchyma is as shown below. Which of the following is false about this condition?

choices.text: It is an autosomal recessive condition
Brain shows loss of myelin and oligodendrocytes

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette showing a 4-month-old baby with motor signs like stiffness and weakness with rapid progression and histology of brain showing characteristic globoid cells is suggestive of Krabbe disease where peripheral nerves are equally affected.

Krabbe's disease :

Krabbe's disease is also known as Globoid cell leukodystrophy. It is a neurodegenerative disorder with severe myelin loss and the presence of globoid bodies in white matter.

It is an autosomal recessive leukodystrophy resulting from a deficiency of galactocerebroside β-galactosidase, the enzyme required for the catabolism of galactocerebroside to ceramide and galactose. As a result, an alternative catabolic pathway shunts galactocerebroside to galactosylsphingosine, a compound toxic to both oligodendrocytes and astrocytes.

The onset of symptoms is between 3 and 6 months of age, dominated by motor signs such as stiffness and weakness Survival beyond the age of 2 years is uncommon. The brain shows loss of myelin and oligodendrocytes with a similar process affecting the peripheral nerves.

A unique and diagnostic feature of Krabbe disease is the aggregation of engorged macrophages (globoid cells) in the brain parenchyma and around blood vessels.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male patient presented with a mass on his right thigh. A biopsy of the lesion is taken and molecular analysis revealed t(12;16).  Which of the following is not seen on histological examination of this lesion?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette showing a mass on his thigh with molecular analysis showing t(12;16) is suggestive of myxoid liposarcoma. Scattered atypical spindle cells are not histopathological findings of myxoid liposarcoma, but rather of well-differentiated liposarcoma.

Liposarcoma: 

It is the most common sarcoma in adults and is usually seen in 5th to 6th decade of life. They commonly occur in the deep soft tissues of the proximal extremities and in the retroperitoneum.

Histologically the liposarcomas are divided into three subtypes:

  • Well-differentiated liposarcoma: It consists of mature adipocytes with scattered atypical spindle cells. 
  • Myxoid liposarcoma: It contains an abundant basophilic extracellular matrix, arborizing capillaries, and primitive cells at various stages of adipocyte differentiation resembling fetal fat. It is associated with t(12;16).
  • Pleomorphic liposarcoma: It consists of sheets of anaplastic cells with bizarre nuclei and few immature adipocytes. These are termed as lipoblasts.

The following image shows the histology of myxoid liposarcoma :

questions.text: Which of the following is not a common location of Ghon's focus?
questions.solution:
Primary bronchus does not describe the location of Ghon's focus as the tubercle bacilli implants in distal air spaces, not proximal.

Ghon's focus is the gray-white inflammation with consolidation. It is seen in primary tuberculosis. The common location of Ghon's focus is the lower part of the upper lobe or the upper part of the lower lobe, usually close to the pleura. Ghon's focus along with the nodal involvement is called the Ghon's complex.

The following image shows the presence of Ghon's complex on chest X-ray :

 

Primary tuberculosis occurs on first exposure. The following findings may be seen:

Ghon's focus - focus of infection located subpleurally
Ghon's complex - Ghon's focus with lymph node involvement
Ranke complex - a calcified Ghon's complex

Secondary tuberculosis occurs due to the reactivation of TB. It affects the apex. The following findings may be seen:

Puhl's complex - supraclavicular lesion
Assmann's complex - infraclavicular lesion

Disseminated or miliary tuberculosis is characterised by 1-2 mm disseminated lesions all over the lung. The following findings may be associated:

Simon's focus - early hematogenous seeding in the apex of lungs
Rich focus - tuberculous caseous foci in brain, meninges and spinal cord

questions.text: A middle-aged man with emphysema was found to have elevated liver transaminases. His liver biopsy image is given below. These inclusions are periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive and diastase-resistant. Which type of emphysema does this patient most likely have?
questions.solution:
The presence of PAS-positive and diastase-resistant inclusion bodies in the hepatocytes is suggestive of α1 antitrypsin deficiency. This condition is associated with panacinar type of emphysema.

α1-antitrypsin (α1AT) deficiency is an autosomal-recessive disorder of protein misfolding that results in impaired secretion of α1 antitrypsin (α1AT) into the serum. Deficiency of α1AT protein results in excessive degradation of alveoli by neutrophil elastase causing panacinar emphysema.

It also causes liver disease as a consequence of the abnormal accumulation of the misfolded protein within hepatocytes. Hepatocellular carcinoma develops in some cases. Liver biopsy round-to-oval cytoplasmic globular inclusions in hepatocytes that are strongly periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive and diastase-resistant. 

Emphysema is a condition in which the air spaces distal to the terminal bronchiole are abnormally enlarged due to irreversible damage to their walls. This results in poor gaseous exchange and progressive air trapping.

Emphysema can be of four major types depending on the areas affected: (1) centriacinar, (2) panacinar, (3) paraseptal, and (4) irregular.

Out of these, only the pan-acinar type is associated with α1-antitrypsin (α1AT) deficiency and liver damage. In this type of emphysema, the acini from the respiratory bronchiole to the terminal blind alveoli are uniformly enlarged.

Related Pearl: Types of emphysema

Emphysema is classified according to its anatomic distribution within the lobule.

Type Area involved Other features

Centriacinar (most common)
  • Central part of acinus (respiratory bronchiole)
  • Upper lobes of lung
  • Commonly seen in smokers
Panacinar
  • Entire acinus (respiratory bronchiole + alveoli)
  • Lower lobes of lung
  • Commonly seen in young non-smokers
  • Associated with α-1 antitrypsin deficiency
Paraseptal
  • Distal part of acinus (alveoli)
  • Subpleural region
  • Commonly seen in young adults 
  • Increased risk for spontaneous pneumothorax 
Irregular
  • Focal and irregular involvement of acinus
  • Areas of the lung near scar tissue 
  • Not usually seen in COPD

questions.text:
A nephrectomy specimen of a 40-year-old man showed the following histological picture. It is known to metastasize to the following sites. Arrange them in order of decreasing frequency.
  1. Regional lymph nodes
  2. Adrenal glands
  3. Bones
  4. Liver
questions.solution:
The given image is of chromophobe renal cell carcinoma. It can be identified by the presence of pale eosinophilic cells arranged in the form of solid sheets. Some cells are having a perinuclear halo. The sites of metastasis of renal cell carcinoma (RCC) in order of decreasing frequency are the lung, bones with a predominant osteolytic lesion, regional lymph nodes, liver, adrenal, and brain (3, 1, 4, 2).

Chromophobe carcinoma is thought to arise from the intercalated cells of the collecting ducts. It is composed of cells with prominent cell membranes and pale eosinophilic cytoplasm, usually with a halo around the nucleus. It shows large cells having a plant-cell-like appearance. They are arranged in solid sheets with a concentration of the largest cells around blood vessels.

Cytogenetic examination of the tumor shows multiple chromosome losses and extreme hypodiploidy. It has an excellent prognosis compared to clear cell and papillary cancers. 

Close differential diagnoses are as follows:

  • Oncocytoma: They also consist of large eosinophilic cells having small, round, benign-appearing nuclei that have large nucleoli. However, they do not show perinuclear halo.
  • Clear cell RCC: Pale eosinophilic cytoplasm in chromophobe RCC distinguishes it from the clear appearance of the cytoplasm due to the accumulation of glycogen and lipids in clear-cell RCC.

Below image shows clear cell renal carcinoma

questions.text: An autopsy of a 38-year-old male patient who died of cardiac failure showed the following histopathological image of the endocardium. Which of the following best describes the form of vegetation found in this condition?

choices.text: Small, warty vegetations along the line of closure of the valve leaflets
Large, irregular masses on valve cusps and chordae
Small, bland vegetations on the line of closure
Small to medium sized vegetations on either sides of the valve

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette with histopathology showing Anitschkow cells and Aschoff bodies are pathognomic of the rheumatic fever (RF) phase of rheumatic heart disease (RHD). It is associated with small, warty vegetations along the lines of closure of the valve leaflets.

RF is an acute, immunologically mediated, multisystem inflammatory disease classically occurring a few weeks after group A streptococcal pharyngitis. RHD is principally characterized by deforming fibrotic valvular disease, particularly the mitral valve.

Important pathological findings in rheumatic fever are:

  • Inflammation in the three layers of the heart can result in endocarditis, myocarditis, pericarditis, or pancarditis.
  • Inflammation of the endocardium and the left side valves can lead to fibrinoid necrosis. Over these areas of necrosis, small vegetations can be seen along the lines of closure, called verrucae.
  • In the subendocardium, irregular thickenings called MacCallum plaques can be present.
  • Aschoff bodies are collections of lymphocytes (primarily T cells), scattered plasma cells, and plump-activated macrophages (called Anitschkow cells). The Anitschkow cells have abundant cytoplasm and nuclei with chromatin that is centrally condensed into a slender, wavy ribbon. Hence they are also called caterpillar cells.
  • Mitral valve in chronic RHD shows leaflet thickening, commissural fusion and shortening, and thickening and fusion of the tendinous cords.This leads to narrowing of the mitral orifice, giving it a fish mouth appearance.

Image: Histology of a rheumatic fever patient showing Aschoff bodies and Anitschkow cells.

Related Pearl: Named Cells in Histopathology

Named cells

Condition
