questions.text: A 66-year-old man who has been diagnosed with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) comes for a follow-up visit when he is found to be anemic. Bone marrow biopsy show marrow fibrosis. Peripheral blood smear findings include occasional myelocytes, a few tear-drop red blood cells (RBCs), and two nucleated RBCs per 100 white cells. Erythrocytes are normochromic and normocytic. What is the most common cause of this form of anemia?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a patient with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) in the spent phase (marrow fibrosis and cytopenia) is highly suggestive of myelophthisic anemia. The most common cause is metastatic cancer from the breast, lung, and prostate. 

Points in favor of the diagnosis:

  • Myelocytes + nucleated RBCs = leukoerythroblastic image
  • Presence of tear-drop cells 
  • Myeloproliferative neoplasm in the spent phase of the disease presents with this anemic picture.

Myelophthisic anemia: It is a form of marrow failure in which space-occupying lesions replace normal marrow elements. The most common cause is metastatic cancer. The metastasis can be from carcinomas of the breast, lung, and prostate. Apart from these, granulomatous diseases and myeloproliferative neoplasms can also cause myelophthisic anemia. 

Blood picture and marrow findings:

Peripheral blood smear usually shows a normocytic and normochromic form of anemia. A characteristic leukoerythroblastic smear aids with diagnosis. The morphology of the circulating erythrocyte is highly abnormal, which could be nucleated RBCs, teardrops, and shape distortions. An elevated WBC count mimicking a leukemoid reaction is sometimes seen, with circulating myelocytes, promyelocytes, and myeloblasts. Giant size platelets are often seen with thrombocytosis. Bone marrow tap is characteristically dry.

questions.text: The ECG of a 62-year-old hypertensive patient is given below. What change does the myosin undergo in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given ECG of a hypertensive patient is suggestive of left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH), where the alpha isoform of myosin heavy chain is replaced by the beta isoform. 

The given ECG shows tall left precordial R waves, i.e in the V1 lead, and deep right precordial S waves in the V5 and V6 leads, which are over 35 mm. It also shows the presence of repolarization abnormalities in the form of ST depression with T-wave inversions in the right precordial leads. An increased limb lead voltage (R-aVL) also signifies the presence of left ventricular hypertrophy.

ECG findings suggestive of LVH:

  • S-V1 + R-V5/V6 >35 mm
  • R-aVL + SV3 >20 mm in women and >28 mm in men
  • ST depression with T wave inversion- strain pattern

Causes of LVH:

  • Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Aortic stenosis
  • Aortic regurgitation
  • Mitral regurgitation
  • Coarctation of the aorta
  • Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

Cardiac hypertrophy is associated with a switch in gene expression from genes that encode adult-type contractile proteins to genes that encode distinct fetal isoforms of the same proteins. One such example is where the alpha isoform of myosin heavy chain is replaced by the beta isoform, which has a slower, more energetically economical contraction.

Cardiac hypertrophy is also associated with increased atrial natriuretic factor gene expression. This causes salt secretion by the kidney and decreases blood volume and pressure, thereby reducing hemodynamic load.

Several regressive changes occur in the myocardial fibers when the enlargement of muscle mass is no longer able to cope with the increased burden. They include degradation and loss of myofibrillar contractile elements. In extreme cases, myocyte death can occur. The net result of these changes is cardiac failure.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male who is a known diabetic and hypertensive suffers an episode of cardiac arrest. During his episode of myocardial infarction, which of the following is the least susceptible to injury considering the episode was transient and not severe?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette showing an episode of cardiac arrest causes a state of global cerebral hypoxia which occurs when there is a generalized reduction of cerebral perfusion. Astrocytes are the least likely susceptible to injury as they are least sensitive among the given options.

Causes for global cerebral hypoxia/ischemia :

  • Generalized reduction of cerebral perfusion - cardiac arrest, shock, and severe hypotension
  • Decreased oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood - carbon monoxide poisoning

Hierarchy of sensitivity to hypoxia/ ischemia of CNS cells: neurons are the most sensitive, although glial cells (oligodendrocytes and astrocytes) are also vulnerable.

Most sensitive neurons in the brain, susceptible to ischemic insult are-

Cells

Region

Pyramidal neurons

Hippocampus(espe­cially area CA1, also referred to as Sommer sector)

Purkinje cells

Cerebellum

Pyramidal neurons

Cerebral cortex(the watershed zones)

Astrocytes are more resistant to cerebral ischemia than neurons and die by delayed necrosis and gliosis.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male patient comes to the OPD with localized bone pain in his right chest for the last 6 months. He also complains of fever, chills, and weight loss for the same duration. On history, he mentions that he was diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis about 2 years back. A biopsy of the rib reveals caseous necrosis and granulomas on histology. Which of the following is not a complication of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette showing localized pain, fever, chills, and weight loss along with histology showing caseous necrosis and granulomas is suggestive of tuberculous osteomyelitis. Brodie's abscess is not a complication of tubercular osteomyelitis.

Brodie's abscess is an intraosseous abscess related to a focus of subacute pyogenic osteomyelitis, usually affecting the metaphysis of the long bones. 

Tuberculous osteomyelitis/Mycobacterial osteomyelitis: 

Mycobacteria are usually blood-borne, originating from a focus of active visceral disease during the early stages of primary infection. The bones are involved as a result of direct extension from a pulmonary focus into a rib or from tracheobronchial nodes into adjacent vertebrae.

The histologic findings typical of tuberculous osteomyelitis are granulomatous inflammation and caseous necrosis.

Majority of mycobacterial osteomyelitis cases involve the spine as Pott disease. Destruction of discs and vertebrae results in compression fractures that culminate in scoliosis, kyphosis, and neurologic deficits. Other complications of tuberculous osteomyelitis are :

  • Tuberculous arthritis
  • Sinus tract formation
  • Psoas abscess
  • Amyloidosis

In tuberculous osteomyelitis, weight-bearing joints (the spine in 40% of cases, the hips in 13%, and the knees in 10%) are most commonly affected.

questions.text: The hand radiograph of a woman who complained of swelling and pain in her left-hand shows the following finding. Laboratory investigations show elevated levels of serum parathormone, calcium, and low levels of serum phosphate. Surgical resection of the mass reveals a brown color. Increased activity of which of the following is seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The patient has primary hyperparathyroidism as she has elevated levels of parathormone and calcium, with decreased levels of serum phosphate. The radiograph shows the presence of an osteolytic lesion in her left second metacarpal. The tumor on excision was brown in color. All these features suggest that the patient has a brown tumor. Increased activity of osteoclasts is seen in this condition.

Parathyroid hormone (PTH)-induced increased osteoclast activity in hyperparathyroidism results in bone loss which predisposes to microfractures and secondary hemorrhages. This results in an influx of macrophages and ingrowth of reparative fibrous tissue creating a mass of reactive tissue known as a brown tumor.

In the areas of bone resorption, the bone tissue is replaced with proliferating fibrous tissue, hemorrhage, and necrosed tissue. The hemorrhage leads to the accumulation of hemoglobin which is converted to hemosiderin. This hemosiderin gives it a brown color. The brown color is the result of vascularity, hemorrhage, and hemosiderin deposition.

Generalized osteitis fibrosa cystica / Von Recklinghausen disease of bone : 

It is a disease that is the hallmark of severe hyperparathyroidism and exhibits a combination of

  1. Increased osteoclast activity
  2. Peritrabecular fibrosis
  3. Cystic brown tumors

Hyperparathyroidism is caused by elevated parathyroid hormone and is classified into primary, secondary, and tertiary types.

Primary hyperparathyroidism Secondary hyperparathyroidism Tertiary hyperparathyroidism

An increased overproduction of parathyroid hormone (PTH) by parathyroid gland

 Compensatory hypersecretion of PTH in response to prolonged hypocalcemia Persistent hypersecretion of PTH even after the cause of prolonged hypocalcemia is corrected
Parathyroid  adenoma or hyperplasia Chronic renal failure A state of severe hyperparathyroidism in patients with CKD that requires surgery

The clinical manifestations of hyperparathyroidism can be summarized as “painful bones, renal stones, abdominal groans, and psychic moans.” Skeletal manifestations of hyperparathyroidism include bone resorption, osteitis fibrosa cystica, and brown tumors. Renal changes include nephrolithiasis (stones) and nephrocalcinosis.

questions.text: During the pathology lab discussion classes, the following section of the lung tissue was displayed. Which of the following is not one of the four conditions that make up for more than 50% of the cases associated with the histopathological changes found in the given slide?
questions.solution:
The image shows the lung histopathology of diffuse alveolar damage which is the characteristic histologic finding of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). More than 50% of the cases are associated with sepsis, mechanical injuries, diffuse pulmonary infections, and gastric aspiration. Inhaled smoke is not one of them.

ARDS is a manifestation of severe acute lung injury (ALI) and is characterized histologically by diffuse alveolar damage (DAD). Inflammatory changes lead to the development of increased pulmonary vascular permeability, edema, and epithelial cell death. Damage to the pulmonary endothelial cells and pneumocytes, with inflammation, is the key initiating event and the basis of lung damage. 

Histopathology: A waxy, hyaline membrane lines the alveolar walls. The membrane is composed of fibrin-rich edema fluid mixed with necrotic epithelial cell remnants. Congestion, interstitial and intra-alveolar edema, inflammation, and fibrin deposition are seen in addition to the diffuse alveolar damage. This finding is seen in lung tissue of a COVID-19 patient (diffuse viral pulmonary infection).

Causes of ARDS

  • Infections :
    • Sepsis
    • Diffuse pulmonary infections: Viral, Mycoplasma, and Pneumocystis pneumonia; miliary tuberculosis
    • Gastric aspiration
  • Physical/Injury
    • Mechanical trauma including head injuries
    • Pulmonary contusions
    • Near-drowning
    • Fractures with fat embolism
    • Burns
    • Ionizing radiation
  • Inhaled Irritants
    • Oxygen toxicity
    • Smoke
    • Irritant gases and chemicals
  • Chemical Injury
    • Heroin or methadone overdose
    • Acetylsalicylic acid
    • Barbiturate overdose
    • Paraquat
  • Hematologic Conditions
    • Transfusion-associated lung injury (TRALI)
    • Disseminated intravascular coagulation
  • Pancreatitis
  • Uremia
  • Cardiopulmonary Bypass
  • Hypersensitivity Reactions
    • Organic solvents
    • Drugs

questions.text: The gross appearance of a liver pictured while conducting an autopsy of a chronic alcoholic is as shown below. This finding is a result of the activation of which of the following cells?
questions.solution:
The gross appearance of the liver showing classic micronodular cirrhosis seen in alcoholic steatofibrosis is a result of the activation of stellate cells.

Stellate cells :

Scarring of the liver (cirrhosis) in which hepatocytes are surrounded by fibrosis (with or without a regenerative response) represents a common endpoint for chronic liver disease. The principal cell type involved in scar deposition in the liver is the hepatic stellate cell. 

Hepatic stellate cells are present in the space of Disse and store lipids, including vitamin A. They are mesenchymal in origin. But in several cases of acute and chronic injury to the liver, these cells are activated and differentiate into highly fibrogenic myofibroblasts.

The activation of stellate cells can be varied and includes the following:

  • Inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α) are produced by Kupffer cells, macrophages, etc.
  • Altered interactions with the extracellular matrix
  • Toxins and reactive oxygen species (ROS)

These activated stellate cells are then converted into myofibroblasts through signals transmitted by platelet-derived growth factor receptor β and by several cytokines (TGF-β, IL-17) and chemokines. Extracellular matrix deposition and scarring commence in the space of Disse. Eventually, the surviving hepatocytes are encircled by fibrous septa and give rise to diffuse scarring (cirrhosis). Hepatocytes replicate in an effort to restore the parenchyma which gives rise to regenerative nodules, a feature seen in most cirrhotic livers.

There are three distinctive, overlapping forms of alcoholic liver injury:

  • Hepatic steatosis (fatty liver)
    • Fatty change is completely reversible if there is abstention from further intake of alcohol.
    • Starts in the centrilobular area
  • Alcoholic (steato) hepatitis
    • Ballooning degeneration and necrosis
    • Mallory–Denk bodies/ Mallory hyaline - These are tangled skeins of intermediate filaments such as keratin 8 and keratin 18 that are partially degraded and ubiquitinated.
    • Neutrophilic reaction
  • Alcoholic steatofibrosis
    • Perisinusoidal fibrosis and sclerosis of the central vein
    • Micronodular/ Laennec cirrhosis
    • Irreversible

Continued damage of the liver with alcohol progresses to portal/ periportal fibrosis, and then to bridging fibrosis and cirrhosis, which is micronodular (“Laennec cirrhosis”) The characteristic diffuse nodularity of the surface is induced by the underlying fibrous scarring.

Other options:

Option B: Kupffer cells are hepatic macrophages, which are responsible for removing cellular and microbial debris from the circulation, and also for secreting cytokines involved in defense.

Option C: Hepatic stem cells are undifferentiated, pluripotential cells and reside around the canals of Hering.

Option D: The endothelial cells are typically flat cells, each with a central nucleus, and they are joined to each other by junctional complexes. Their cytoplasm contains numerous transcytotic vesicles.

questions.text: A patient who underwent renal transplantation 8 months ago presents with pain at the site of the transplanted kidney, fever, and malaise. The renal biopsy findings of the kidney allograft are shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of acute pyelonephritis after 8 months of kidney transplantation and the image showing enlarged tubular epithelial cells, nuclear inclusions, and interstitial inflammation suggest nephropathy caused by polyomavirus.

Polyomavirus is a viral pathogen causing pyelonephritis in kidney allografts. Immunosuppression of the allograft recipient can lead to reactivation of latent infection by polyomavirus and the development of nephropathy. This form of pyelonephritis is referred to as polyomavirus nephropathy.

Histopathology shows infection of tubular epithelial cell nuclei, leading to nuclear enlargement and intranuclear inclusions visible by light microscopy. An inflammatory interstitial inflammatory response is present.

Electron microscopy shows the presence of intranuclear viral inclusions, as seen in the image below.

Image A shows big clusters of viral particles in the nucleus and image B shows degrading organelles:


The following image shows enlarged tubular epithelial cells with nuclear inclusions (arrows):


Treatment: Reduction of immunosuppression.

Common opportunistic infections in kidney transplant recipients:

Early (1-6 months) :

  • Pneumocystis carinii (Option C)
  • Cytomegalovirus (Option A)
  • Legionella
  • Listeria (Option D)
  • Hepatitis B 
  • Hepatitis C

Late ( >6 months) : 

  • Aspergillus
  • Nocardia
  • BK virus (polyoma)
  • Herpes zoster
  • Hepatitis B
  • Hepatitis C

questions.text: The autopsy of a 1-year-old child who died of congestive cardiac failure revealed multiple tumours of the heart located in the ventricles. The histopathologic findings is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given histological slide shows abundant spider cells which are characteristic of cardiac rhabdomyoma.

Microscopically, cardiac rhabdomyomas are composed of bizarre, markedly enlarged myocytes. Histologic processing of the sample usually removes the glycogen and artifactually reduces the cytoplasm to thin strands. These strands stretch from the nucleus to the surface membrane. This gives an appearance that resembles a spider and is hence referred to as spider cells.

Rhabdomyomas are mostly seen in the first year of life. They are discovered when there is an obstruction to a valvular orifice or cardiac chamber. Approximately half the cardiac rhabdomyomas are due to sporadic mutations. The other 50% of cases are associated with tuberous sclerosis. They are usually multiple and appear in ventricles preferentially. They often regress spontaneously and may, therefore, be considered as hamartomas and not true neoplasms.

The image below shows histopathological findings of cardiac rhabdomyoma with spider cells.

Myxomas are the most common primary tumour of the adult heart. Unlike rhabdomyomas, they are usually single and the common site of origin is the region of the fossa ovalis in the atrial septum. Histology reveals the presence of stellate or globular myxoma cells embedded within an abundant acid mucopolysaccharide ground substance. There are characteristic vessel-like or glandlike structures.

Papillary fibroelastomas are mainly present in the valves. It appears as a cluster of hairlike projections up to 1 cm in length.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with thyroid swelling. The histological examination of the swelling is shown below. What type of amyloid deposits are seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The slide is showing the presence of amyloid-rich stroma (pinkish material) and nests of polygonal cells, suggestive of medullary carcinoma thyroid. The major fibril protein that gets deposited is A Cal, which is derived from calcitonin.

Microscopic deposits of localized amyloid may be found in certain conditions such as:

  • Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid gland
  • Islet tumors of the pancreas
  • Pheochromocytomas
  • Undifferentiated carcinomas of the stomach
  • Islets of Langerhans in individuals with type 2 diabetes mellitus
